message.content:
cs.CL, cs.SI, cs.IR, cs.LG, cs.CY 

This paper is likely to belong to the arXiv CS sub-category of cs.CL (Computation and Language) as it deals with natural language processing (NLP) tasks such as adverse drug reaction (ADR) mention extraction from tweets using recurrent neural networks (RNNs). Additionally, the paper also involves the use of semi-supervised learning techniques, which is a common research area in the cs.CL sub-category. 

The paper may also belong to the sub-category of cs.SI (Social and Information Networks) as it deals with analyzing social media data (Twitter) to extract ADR mentions. 

Furthermore, the paper may belong to the sub-category of cs.IR (Information Retrieval) as it involves the task of extracting relevant information (ADR mentions) from a large corpus of unstructured text data (tweets). 

The sub-category of cs.LG (Machine Learning) is also a likely fit as the paper involves the use of machine learning techniques such as RNNs and co-training to improve the performance of ADR mention extraction. 

Lastly, the paper may belong to the sub-category of cs.CY (Computers and Society) as it deals with a topic related to healthcare and the impact of social media on healthcare-related information dissemination.
